<A NAME="eolPage181"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(1)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Description of Business
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Worthington Armstrong Venture (the&nbsp;Company) is a general
	partnership, formed in June&nbsp;1992, between Armstrong Ventures, Inc. (Armstrong), a subsidiary of Armstrong World Industries, Inc., and The Worthington Steel Company (Worthington), a Delaware corporation (a subsidiary of Worthington Industries,
	Inc.). Its business is to manufacture and market suspension systems for commercial and residential ceiling markets throughout the world. The Company has manufacturing plants located in the United States, France, the United Kingdom, the People&#146;s
	Republic of China, and India.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company closed its manufacturing plant in Spain during 2013 transferring its production capabilities to
	other European locations. The total cost of the plant closure was $3,934, which included $2,009 severance pay, $1,278 capital and inventory obsolescence, and $647 other closing related costs. All closing costs were incurred and expensed during 2013
	and recorded in cost of goods sold.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(2)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Summary of Significant Accounting Policies
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:6PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(a)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Use of Estimates
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	These consolidated financial statements are
	prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (U.S.&nbsp;GAAP) and include management estimates and judgments, where appropriate. Actual results could differ from those estimates. Significant
	items subject to such estimates and assumptions include the carrying amount of property, plant, and equipment and goodwill, valuation allowances for receivables and inventories, valuation of derivatives, and assets and obligations related to
	employee benefits.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of the Company and its subsidiaries. All significant
	intercompany transactions have been eliminated.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(b)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Revenue Recognition
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognizes revenue from the sale of products
	when title transfers, generally on the date of shipment and collection of the relevant receivable is probable. At the time of shipment, a provision is made for estimated applicable discounts and losses that reduce revenue. The Company&#146;s
	standard sales terms are &#147;Free On Board&#148; (FOB) shipping point. The Company has some sales terms that are FOB destination.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Sales
	taxes collected from customers and remitted to governmental authorities are accounted for on a net basis and, therefore, are excluded from revenues in the consolidated statements of income and comprehensive income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	7
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage182"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(c)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognizes all
	derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities in the balance sheet at their respective fair values. For derivatives designated in hedging relationships, changes in the fair value are recognized in accumulated other comprehensive income, to
	the extent the derivative is effective at offsetting the changes in cash flows being hedged until the hedged item affects earnings. For derivatives not designated as hedges or that do not meet the criteria for hedge accounting, all changes in fair
	value are recorded immediately to profit or loss.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(d
</I>
</B>
	)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Advertising Costs
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognizes advertising expense as incurred.
	Advertising expense was $1,116, $1,049, and $940 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014, and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(e
</I>
</B>
	)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Research and Development Expenditures
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company recognizes research and
	development expense as expenditures are incurred. Total research and development expense was $4,048, $4,065, and $3,811 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014, and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(f
</I>
</B>
	)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Taxes
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is a general partnership in the United States, and
	accordingly, generally, U.S.&nbsp;federal and state income taxes are the responsibility of the two general partners. Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognized for foreign subsidiaries for taxes estimated to be payable in future years
	based upon differences between the financial reporting and tax bases of assets and liabilities. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined using enacted rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years the temporary differences are
	expected to be recovered or settled. The Company recognizes the effect of uncertain income tax positions only if those positions are more likely than not of being sustained. Recognized income tax positions are measured at the largest amount that is
	greater than 50% likely of being realized. Changes in recognition or measurement are reflected in the period in which the change in judgment occurs.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(g
</I>
</B>
	)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Cash and Cash Equivalents
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash short-term investments that have original
	maturities of three&nbsp;months or less when purchased are considered to be cash equivalents.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(h)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Short-term Investments
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Short-term investments that have maturity dates greater
	than three&nbsp;months consist primarily of one&nbsp;year certificates of deposits.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(i)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Trade Accounts Receivable
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Trade accounts receivable are recorded at the invoiced
	amount and do not bear interest. The Company maintains an allowance for doubtful accounts for estimated losses inherent in its accounts
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	8
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage183"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	receivable portfolio. In establishing the required allowance, management considers historical losses, current receivables aging, and existing industry and national economic data. Account balances
	are charged off against the allowance after all means of collection have been exhausted and the potential for recovery is considered remote. The Company does not have any
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	off-balance-sheet
</FONT>
</FONT>
	credit exposure related to its customers.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(j)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
</I>
</B>
<B>
<I>
	Inventories
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Inventories are valued at the lower of cost or market.
	Cost is determined on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	first-in,
</FONT>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	first-out
</FONT>
	method.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(k)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Long-Lived
</FONT>
	Assets
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Property, plant, and
	equipment are stated at cost, with accumulated depreciation and amortization deducted to arrive at net book value. Depreciation charges are determined generally on the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	straight-line
</FONT>
	basis over the useful lives
	as follows: buildings, 30&nbsp;years; machinery and equipment, 5 to 15&nbsp;years; and leasehold improvements over the shorter of 10&nbsp;years or the life of the lease. Impairment losses are recorded when indicators of impairment are present and
	the undiscounted cash flows estimated to be generated by those assets are less than the assets&#146; carrying amount. If an impairment exists, the asset is reduced to fair value.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(l)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Goodwill
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Goodwill represents the excess of the aggregate purchase price over the
	fair value of the net assets acquired in a purchase business combination. Goodwill is tested for impairment at least annually. The impairment tests performed in 2015, 2014, and 2013 did not result in an impairment of the Company&#146;s goodwill.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%">
	&nbsp;
</TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
<I>
	(m)
</I>
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
<I>
	Foreign Currency Translation and Transactions
</I>
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:8%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For subsidiaries with functional
	currencies other than the U.S.&nbsp;dollar, income statement items are translated into dollars at average exchange rates throughout the year and balance sheet items are translated at
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	year-end
</FONT>
	exchange rates.
	Gains or losses on foreign currency transactions are recognized in other income (expense), net in the accompanying consolidated statements of income. Gains and losses on foreign currency translation are recognized in accumulated other comprehensive
	income in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(3)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Accounts Receivable
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company sells its products to select, preapproved customers
	whose businesses are directly affected by changes in economic and market conditions. The Company considers these factors and the financial condition of each customer when establishing its allowance for losses from doubtful accounts. The allowance
	for doubtful accounts was $571 and $622, at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(5)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company uses an interest rate swap to
	manage its exposure related to changes in interest rates on its
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	variable-rate
</FONT>
	private placement note and uses derivative instruments to manage its exposure to steel price fluctuations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The private placement note through New York Life Insurance Company is
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	variable-rate
</FONT>
	London Interbank
	Offered Rate (LIBOR) debt. The debt obligation exposes the Company to variability in interest payments due to changes in interest rates. On July&nbsp;16, 2013, the Company entered into a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	LIBOR-based
</FONT>
	interest
	rate swap agreement to manage fluctuations in cash flows resulting from changes in the benchmark interest rate of LIBOR. The swap changes the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	variable-rate
</FONT>
	cash flow exposure on the private placement note to
	fixed cash flows. Under the terms of the interest rate swap, the Company receives
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	LIBOR-based
</FONT>
	variable interest rate payments and makes fixed interest rate payments, thereby creating the equivalent of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	fixed-rate
</FONT>
	debt for the notional amount of its debt hedged. The swap has a notional amount of $50,000 maturing in July&nbsp;2020, under the terms of which the Company pays a fixed rate of 2.136% and receives
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-month
</FONT>
	LIBOR. This swap is designed as a cash flow hedge.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In 2013, the Company entered into contracts
	with Worthington as the counterparty to manage the price risk associated with fluctuations in market prices for steel. These contracts do not meet the requirements to qualify for hedge accounting. Accordingly, the steel derivatives are adjusted to
	current fair value at the end of each period through earnings. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the Company had no outstanding steel derivatives. The loss on the steel derivatives recognized in earnings within cost of goods sold for the years
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 was $0 and $1, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	10
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage185"></A>

	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE

	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014

	During 2015, Goodwill increased by $8,037 as a result of the acquisition in

<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(8)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Fair Value of Financial Instruments
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company does not hold or issue financial
	instruments for trading purposes.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The carrying amounts of cash and cash equivalents,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	short-term
</FONT>
	investments, accounts receivable, and accounts payable approximate their fair value due to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	short-term
</FONT>
	maturity of these instruments. The carrying value and estimated fair value of debt was $243,500 and
	$241,100, respectively, at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The carrying value and estimated fair value of debt was $238,000 and $239,500, respectively, at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The fair value of the Company&#146;s debt is based on the amount of future cash flows discounted using rates the Company would currently be
	able to realize for similar instruments of comparable maturity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Fair value is defined as the exchange price that would be received for an
	asset or paid to transfer a liability (an exit price) in the principal or most advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date. U.S.&nbsp;GAAP establishes a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	three-level
</FONT>
	fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value. The three&nbsp;levels of inputs used to measure fair value are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Level&nbsp;1 &#150; Quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Level&nbsp;2 &#150; Observable inputs other than quoted prices included in Level&nbsp;1, such as quoted prices for similar assets and
	liabilities in active markets; quoted prices for identical or similar assets and liabilities in markets that are not active; or other inputs that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Level&nbsp;3 &#150; Unobservable inputs that are supported by little or no market activity and that are significant to the fair value of the
	assets or liabilities. This includes certain pricing models, discounted cash flow methodologies, and similar techniques that use significant unobservable inputs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Assets measured at fair value on a recurring basis are summarized below:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_116"></A>

	note&nbsp;5. The Company does not have any significant financial or nonfinancial assets or liabilities that are valued using Level&nbsp;3 inputs.

<A NAME="eolPage187"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(9)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Debt
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company has a $200,000 revolving credit facility (Facility) with PNC Bank and
	other lenders that was extended for five&nbsp;years on October&nbsp;24, 2013. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, there was $143,500 and $138,000, respectively, outstanding under the Facility. The Company can borrow at rates with a range over
	LIBOR of 1.125% to 1.75%, depending on the Company&#146;s leverage ratio, as defined by the terms of the Facility. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, the rate was 1.68% and 1.42%, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On July&nbsp;1, 2013, the Company issued $50,000 of private placement floating rate debt through New York Life Insurance Company. The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	seven-year
</FONT>
	notes (NY Life Notes) mature on July&nbsp;1, 2020. The NY Life Notes bear interest at a rate of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	one-month
</FONT>
	LIBOR plus a spread of 150 basis points. At
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, there was $50,000 outstanding.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On December&nbsp;23, 2011, the Company issued $50,000 of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	10-year
</FONT>
	private placement notes (Prudential Notes) with Prudential Insurance Company that mature in December&nbsp;2021. At December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, there was $50,000 outstanding. The Prudential Notes bear
	interest at 4.9% that is paid on a quarterly basis.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The debt agreements contain certain restrictive financial covenants, including, among
	others, interest coverage and leverage ratios. The Company was in compliance with its covenants during the years ended and as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(10)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Pension Benefit Programs
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company contributes to the Worthington Industries Deferred
	Profit Sharing Plan for eligible U.S.&nbsp;employees. Costs for this plan were $1,258, $1,284, and $1,160 for 2015, 2014, and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company contributes to
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	government-related
</FONT>
	pension programs in a number of foreign countries. The
	cost for these plans amounted to $531, $504, and $514 for 2015, 2014, and 2013, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company also has a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	U.S.&nbsp;defined-benefit
</FONT>
	pension plan for eligible hourly employees that worked in its former manufacturing plant located in Malvern, Pennsylvania. This plan was curtailed in January&nbsp;2004 due to the
	consolidation of the Company&#146;s East Coast operations, which eliminated the expected future years of service for participants in the plan.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	13
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The accumulated benefit obligation for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	U.S.&nbsp;defined-benefit
</FONT>
	pension plan was $11,185 and $11,795 at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. The unrecognized net loss for the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	defined-benefit
</FONT>
	pension plan that will be amortized from accumulated other comprehensive
	income into net periodic benefit cost over the next fiscal year is $250.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In October&nbsp;2014, the Society of Actuaries (SOA) issued new
	mortality tables that raise life expectancies and thereby indicate the amount of estimated benefit payments to U.S.&nbsp;pension plan&#146;s participants increased. In October&nbsp;2015, the SOA updated the mortality improvement scale that
	accompanies the 2014 mortality table. The updated mortality improvement scale reflects a decrease in the rate of improvements in
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	14
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage189"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	life expectancies in the United States compared with the data in the 2014 mortality improvement scale. The Company incorporated the new SOA improvement scale into the December&nbsp;31, 2015
	measurement of the U.S.&nbsp;pension plan&#146;s benefit obligation.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Pension plan assets are required to be disclosed at fair value in the consolidated financial statements. Fair
	value is defined in note&nbsp;7 &#150; Fair Value of Financial Instruments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	U.S.&nbsp;defined-benefit
</FONT>
	pension plan assets&#146; fair value measurement level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
	Valuation techniques used need to maximize the use of observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following tables
	set forth by level within the fair value hierarchy a summary of the plan&#146;s assets measured at fair value on a recurring basis as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for assets measured at fair value. There have
	been no changes in the methodologies used at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Cash: Consists of cash and cash equivalents. The carrying
	amounts of cash and cash equivalents approximate fair value due to the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	short-term
</FONT>
	maturity of these instruments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Money market funds: The money market investment consists of an institutional investor money market fund, valued at the fund&#146;s net asset
	value (NAV), which is normally calculated at the close of business daily. The fund&#146;s assets are valued as of this time for the purpose of computing the fund&#146;s NAV.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Corporate bonds and U.S.&nbsp;government and agency issues: Consist of investments in individual corporate bonds or government bonds. These
	bonds are each individually valued using a yield curve model, based on observable inputs, which may also incorporate available trade and bid/ask spread data where available.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Common stocks: Consist of investments in common stocks that are valued at the closing price reported on the active market on which the
	individual security is traded.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In developing the 7.25% expected
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	long-term
</FONT>
	rate of return
	assumption, the Company considered its historical returns and reviewed asset class return expectations and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	long-term
</FONT>
	inflation assumptions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The primary investment objective of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	defined-benefit
</FONT>
	pension plan is to achieve
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	long-term
</FONT>
	growth of capital in excess of 7.25% annually, exclusive of contributions or withdrawals. This objective is to be achieved through a balanced portfolio comprising equities, fixed income, and cash
	investments.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	16
</P>

	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(11)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Income Taxes
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is a general partnership in the United States, and
	accordingly, generally, U.S.&nbsp;federal and state income taxes are the responsibility of the two general partners. Therefore, no income tax provision has been recorded on U.S.&nbsp;income. There are no significant differences between the statutory
	income tax rates in foreign countries where the Company operates and the income tax provision recorded in the income statements. No deferred taxes, including withholding taxes, have been provided on the unremitted earnings of foreign subsidiaries as
	the Company&#146;s intention is to invest these earnings permanently.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Deferred tax balances recorded on the balance sheets relate
	primarily to depreciation and other temporary differences such as pensions and inventories. In 2015, the provision for income tax expense was $2,560 comprising $2,512 current and $48 deferred. In 2014, the provision for income tax expense was $3,267
	comprising $3,286 current and $(19) deferred. In 2013, the provision for income tax expense was $3,231 comprising $3,295 current and $(64) deferred.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	17
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage192"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s tax returns remain subject to tax examination by foreign taxing
	authorities for various jurisdictions from 2010&#150;2014. There is no reserve related to these tax years.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(12)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Leases
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company rents certain real estate and equipment. Several leases include
	options for renewal or purchase and contain clauses for payment of real estate taxes and insurance. In most cases, management expects that in the normal course of business, leases will be renewed or replaced by other leases. Minimum rent payments
	under operating leases are recognized on a
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	straight-line
</FONT>
	basis over the term of the lease including any periods of free rent. Rent expense during 2015, 2014, and 2013 amounted to $2,950, $2,581, and $2,835,
	respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Future minimum payments by year and in the aggregate for operating leases having noncancelable lease terms in excess of
	one&nbsp;year are as follows:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Armstrong provides certain selling, promotional, and administrative
	processing services to the Company for which it receives reimbursement. Armstrong purchases grid products from the Company, which are then resold along with Armstrong inventory to the customer. In 2013, the Company sold $820 of equipment and
	materials to Armstrong at their net book value and no gain or loss was recognized on transactions. No equipment and materials were sold to Armstrong in 2014 or 2015.
</P>

<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
<B>
	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	(Dollar amounts in thousands)
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company owed $223 and $336 to Armstrong as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014,
	respectively, which is included in accounts payable to affiliates. Armstrong owed the Company $5,595 and $8,819 for purchases of product as of the same periods, respectively. The Company owed $713 and $404 to Worthington and affiliates of
	Worthington as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively, which are included in accounts payable to affiliates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Worthington, and
	affiliates of Worthington, provide certain administrative processing services, steel processing services, and
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	insurance-related
</FONT>
	coverages to the Company for which it receives reimbursement.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="81%">
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="3%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(15)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Acquisition
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	On March&nbsp;6, 2015, the Company acquired the assets utilized by Fry
	Reglet Corporation (Fry) in the manufacturing of two product lines (the&nbsp;Business). Assets of the Business and the results of the Business&#146;s operations have been included in the consolidated financial statements since the acquisition date.
	Prior to the acquisition, Fry was the sole supplier of those products to the Company. The Company concluded that the assets met the definition of a business under Accounting Standard Codification section 805,
<I>
	Business Combinations
</I>
	, and
	therefore the transaction has been accounted for as a business combination. As a result of the acquisition, the Company has vertically integrated the customer service, design and drawing, and manufacturing processes of the Business.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The total purchase price of $8,400 was paid in cash. The estimated fair value of the identifiable assets acquired at the acquisition date were
	Property, Plant and Equipment of $363, and the remainder recorded as Goodwill in the amount of $8,037.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In connection with the acquisition,
	the Company paid Fry a $500 consulting fee for transition services. The Company incurred acquisition related costs of $240. These consulting fees and acquisition related costs are included within Selling, General, and Administrative expenses.
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:18PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
<B>
	(16)
</B>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
<B>
	Legal Proceedings
</B>
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company is involved in various claims and legal actions arising
	in the ordinary course of business. In the opinion of management, the ultimate disposition of these matters will not have a material adverse effect on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial position, results of operations, or liquidity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	20
</P>

	WORTHINGTON ARMSTRONG VENTURE
</B>

	(17)

	Business and Credit Concentrations
</B>
</TD>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:4%; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Approximately, 16%, 16%, and 16% of net sales were
	to the Company&#146;s largest
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	third-party
</FONT>
	customer for 2015, 2014, and 2013, respectively. The Company&#146;s 10 largest
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	third-party
</FONT>
	customers accounted for
	approximately 53%, 50%, and 50% of the Company&#146;s net sales for 2015, 2014, and 2013 respectively, and approximately 47% and 41% of the Company&#146;s accounts receivable balances at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. See
	note&nbsp;14 for sales to and amounts owed to the Company from Armstrong.
</P>
